RPilot

Distributed Behavior

In Brief

In Brief

In Brief

Problems

  • Neuroscience needs behavior

  • Naturalistic behavior is complex

  • Complex behavior is hardware-intensive

  • Behavior systems are expensive and limited

  • Neuroscience needs behavior

  • Naturalistic behavior is complex

  • Complex behavior is hardware-intensive

    • "Solutions"

  • accept experimental limitations

  • use nonreproducible in-house code

  • perform underpowered experiments

  • be part of the scientific plutocracy

    • Why do we need an rpilot

    • passive presentation won't get us answers, we need animals to be engaged - either to study the active brain or to provide some output readout. We all know we need behavior
    • most behavior experiments are run by in-house code, that's disastrous for reproducibility and transparency.
    • most labs can't afford development time for hardware/software, and so are left w/ stuff that works pretty badly.
    • current solutions are ridiculously expensive, which is bad for scientific equity and access
    • also, systems neuro is begging for a replication crisis with n=3, so expense is a concrete problem for science.

    What is a behavioral system?

    • hardware
    • optionally stimuli
    • task design
    • data storage and management
    • visualize incoming data, monitor state of system
    • UI to control, should be possible to let multiple ppl run your experiments.

    (put on same slide as existing systems)

    What systems exist?

    • bpod
    • pyControl

    main problem is a hardware limitation that causes a software limitation. -> compiler bottleneck

    Raspberry Pis & Python

    being able to run python on the pi lets the system be integrated - the pis run autonomously, and can run whatever code you can write.

    Rpilot design

    • Efficiency
    • Flexibility
    • Reproducibility

    Rpilot structure

    • Structure diagram

    Task Design

    a task is anything that can be expressed in Python

    (aka anything)

    Task Design

    • Tasks are composed of phases (or are continuous) and are combined with some graduation criterion to go between them (or otherwise to change macro-state).
    • Code demo
    • allows concurrency

    • hardware, stimuli can be swapped out.

      • manager system.
    • want to end up with a task as a set of parameters, compare w/ a script.

    Networking structure

    • Treelike

    • drop a node in anywhere

      • plotting example
    • different behavioral topologies

    UI

    • weakest part of program
    • can be used by anyone
    • hides details of task - this is good, changing things mid-experiment is bad.

    data

    • brief comparison w/ other data structures.
    • benefits of HDF5, also plan on moving to database.

    Demos

    • 2afc w/ sound
    • 2afc w/ visual stim
    • 2afc w/ 2 pis and running wheel
    • VR mouse walking experiment

    Benchmarks?

    Expense comparison

    Testing this thing!

     1. 
     2. 
     3. class Terminal(QtGui.QMainWindow):
     4. 
     5.     def __init__(self):
     6.         # type: () -> None
     7.         super(Terminal, self).__init__()
     8. 
     9.         # networking
    10.         self.node = None
    11.         self.networking = None
    12. 
    13.         # data
    14.         self.mice = {}  # Dict of our open mouse objects
    15.         self.pilots = None
    16. 
    17.         # gui
    18.         self.layout = None
    19.         self.widget = None
    20.         self.file_menu = None
    21.         self.tool_menu = None
    22.         self.control_panel = None
    23.         self.data_panel = None
    24.         self.logo = None
    25. 
    26. 
    27.         # logging
    28.         self.logger        = None
    29.         self.log_handler   = None
    30.         self.log_formatter = None
    31. 
    32.         # Load pilots db as ordered dictionary
    33.         with open(prefs.PILOT_DB) as pilot_file:
    34.             self.pilots = json.load(pilot_file, object_pairs_hook=odict)
    35. 
    36.         # Start Logging
    37.         self.init_logging()
    38. 
    39.         # Listen dictionary - which methods to call for different messages
    40.         # Methods are spawned in new threads using handle_message
    41.         self.listens = {
    42.             'STATE': self.l_state, # A Pi has changed state
    43.             'PING' : self.l_ping,  # Someone wants to know if we're alive
    44.             'DATA' : self.l_data,
    45.             'HANDSHAKE': self.l_handshake # a pi is making first contact, telling us its IP
    46.         }
    47. 
    48.         # Make invoker object to send GUI events back to the main thread
    49.         self.invoker = Invoker()
    50.         prefs.add('INVOKER', self.invoker)
    51. 
    52.         self.initUI()
    53. 
    54.         self.node = Net_Node(id="_T",
    55.                              upstream='T',
    56.                              port=prefs.MSGPORT,
    57.                              listens=self.listens)
    58.         self.logger.info("Net Node Initialized")
    59. 
    60.         # Start external communications in own process
    61.         # Has to be after init_network so it makes a new context
    62.         self.networking = Terminal_Networking(self.pilots)
    63.         self.networking.start()
    64.         self.logger.info("Networking object Initialized")
    65. 
    66.         # send an initial ping looking for our pilots
    67.         self.node.send('T', 'INIT')
    68. 
    69.     def init_logging(self):
    70.         """
    71.         Start logging to a timestamped file in `prefs.LOGDIR`
    72.         """
    73. 
    74.         timestr = datetime.datetime.now().strftime('%y%m%d_%H%M%S')
    75.         log_file = os.path.join(prefs.LOGDIR, 'Terminal_Log_{}.log'.format(timestr))
    76. 
    77.         self.logger        = logging.getLogger('main')
    78.         self.log_handler   = logging.FileHandler(log_file)
    79.         self.log_formatter = logging.Formatter("%(asctime)s %(levelname)s : %(message)s")
    80.         self.log_handler.setFormatter(self.log_formatter)
    81.         self.logger.addHandler(self.log_handler)
    82.         self.logger.setLevel(logging.INFO)
    83.         self.logger.info('Terminal Logging Initiated')
    84.

    a note to start
